required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Is Self-action Observation More Effective Than Observing Another Person's Action?
clinical_study.official_title: Is Self-action Observation More Effective Than Observing Another Person's Action During Upper Extremity Functions?

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the study is to compare the possible effects of self-action observation and observation of another person's action on upper extremity functionality, cognitive functions and reaction times.

primary_outcome.time_frame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and immediately after the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: Jebsen-Taylor Hand Function Test will be used

primary_outcome.time_frame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and immediately after the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: Nine-Hole Peg Test will be used

primary_outcome.time_frame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and immediately after the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: Serial Reaction Time Task will be used.

primary_outcome.time_frame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and immediately after the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: d2 Test of Attention will be used.

primary_outcome.time_frame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and immediately after the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: Motor reaction time will be used.

arm_group.description: Participants will watch their own actions during an upper extremity functionality test.
Participants will watch another person's actions during an upper extremity functionality test.

intervention.description: Participants will watch an upper extremity functionality test.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- >18 years old
- willingness
Exclusion Criteria:
- any kind of neurological or musculoskeletal problems
- sight problems
- pain in the upper limb
